summary: Alice, feeling bored sitting with her sister, follows a White Rabbit down a rabbit-hole, finding herself falling down a deep well into a fantastical world. Observing her surroundings during the fall, she lands safely and continues to pursue the Rabbit. Navigating through a locked hallway and after growing smaller from drinking a curious liquid, Alice finds herself unable to reach the key to a door leading to a beautiful garden. She then eats a cake hoping to change size and access the garden.

nodes.label: Alice
nodes.title: The main character of the story who falls down a rabbit-hole into a fantastical world

nodes.label: Alice's sister
nodes.title: Alice's older sister who reads a book without pictures or conversations

nodes.label: White Rabbit
nodes.title: A talking rabbit with pink eyes and a waistcoat who Alice follows down the rabbit-hole

nodes.label: Dinah
nodes.title: Alice's cat who she thinks about during her fall down the rabbit-hole

edges.label: sit by
edges.title: Alice was beginning to get very tired of sitting by her sister on the bank.

edges.label: chase/follow
edges.title: Alice started to her feet and ran across the field after it, burning with curiosity after seeing it with a waistcoat-pocket and a watch; later, she followed the Rabbit as it was worried about being late.

sectionName: CHAPTER II. The Pool of Tears
summary: Alice grows to a gigantic size and ponders on the identity crisis she faces, contemplating if she has been changed overnight. She accidentally shrinks to two feet after using a fan and finds herself swimming in a pool of her own tears. She encounters a mouse, which she tries to befriend, but scares it with talk of cats and dogs. The mouse agrees to tell its history to explain its aversion to cats and dogs, and they swim to shore where other creatures have also gathered.

nodes.label: Alice
nodes.title: The main character, who experiences size changes and adventures in a fantastical world

nodes.label: White Rabbit
nodes.title: A character who Alice follows into Wonderland, prompting her adventures

nodes.label: Duchess
nodes.title: Mentioned by the White Rabbit, a character that Alice thinks about encountering

nodes.label: Ada
nodes.title: A child Alice knows, used by Alice to assert her own identity

nodes.label: Mabel
nodes.title: Another child known to Alice, contrasted with Alice to help her determine her own identity

nodes.label: Mouse
nodes.title: A small creature that Alice encounters while swimming in the pool of tears

edges.label: observe and initiate conversation with
edges.title: "It was the White Rabbit returning, splendidly dressed, with a pair of white kid gloves in one hand and a large fan in the other. So, when the Rabbit came near her, she began, in a low, timid voice, 'If you please, sir—'"

edges.label: worry about
edges.title: "Oh! the Duchess, the Duchess! Oh! won’t she be savage if I’ve kept her waiting!"

edges.label: not be
edges.title: "I’m sure I’m not Ada."

edges.label: not be
edges.title: "and I’m sure I can’t be Mabel."

edges.label: consider talking to and apologize to
edges.title: "Would it be of any use, now, to speak to this mouse? 'Oh, I beg your pardon!' cried Alice hastily, afraid that she had hurt the poor animal’s feelings."

sectionName: CHAPTER III. A Caucus-Race and a Long Tale
summary: A group of wet and uncomfortable animals, including Alice, discuss how to dry off, leading to a confused and unconventional "Caucus-race" that ends with everyone receiving prizes from Alice. Later, as the Mouse relates a tale, Alice's thoughts and interruptions annoy the Mouse, prompting it to leave. Alice's mention of her cat Dinah frightens the birds away, leaving her alone and sad.

nodes.label: Alice
nodes.title: A young girl who finds herself talking with animals and attending a whimsical gathering

nodes.label: Lory
nodes.title: A sulky character in the story that has an argument with Alice about its age

nodes.label: Mouse
nodes.title: A character who seems to be an authority among the assembled creatures, leads the meeting, and shares a long history

nodes.label: Dodo
nodes.title: A character that suggests a Caucus-race to get everyone dry and adjudicates that everyone has won the race

nodes.label: Eaglet
nodes.title: A character that challenges the Dodo's use of complex words and takes part in the Caucus-race

nodes.label: Duck
nodes.title: Another attendee of the meeting, who inquires about the Mouse's story regarding an archbishop

nodes.label: Dinah
nodes.title: Alice's cat, not directly involved in the scene but mentioned by Alice, causing a stir among the animal attendees

nodes.label: Old Crab
nodes.title: A character that speaks to her daughter about maintaining composure

nodes.label: Young Crab
nodes.title: The daughter of the Old Crab who responds snappishly

nodes.label: Magpie
nodes.title: A bird that leaves the gathering early, cautious of night air affecting its throat

nodes.label: Canary
nodes.title: A bird that also leaves after becoming alarmed by Alice's mention of her cat

edges.label: argue & describe
edges.title: Alice had quite a long argument with the Lory. & Alice described Dinah to the Lory as a great cat for catching mice.

edges.label: questioning
edges.title: The Duck questioned the Mouse: "The question is, what did the archbishop find?"

edges.label: appoint
edges.title: The Dodo pointed to Alice, implying that she should give out the prizes.

edges.label: proposition & narrate
edges.title: The Mouse proposed to Alice to have a prize herself. & The Mouse began to narrate its long and sad tale to Alice.

edges.label: inquiry
edges.title: The Lory inquired who Dinah was after Alice mentioned her.

sectionName: CHAPTER IV. The Rabbit Sends in a Little Bill
summary: Alice encounters the White Rabbit, who mistakes her for his servant Mary Ann and sends her to get his gloves and fan. She finds her way to his house and, while searching for the items, drinks from a bottle that causes her to grow huge. Trapped in the house, she scares the Rabbit and his helpers, who then debate ways to remove her, culminating in throwing pebbles at her. These pebbles turn into cakes, and upon eating one, she shrinks and escapes. Once outside, she decides to find her way into a beautiful garden and grows to her correct size with a mushroom that a caterpillar is perched upon.

nodes.label: White Rabbit
nodes.title: A nervous character anxious about displeasing the Duchess

nodes.label: Alice
nodes.title: The young protagonist of the story who experiences the whimsical world around her

nodes.label: The Duchess
nodes.title: Mentioned by the White Rabbit as someone who could have him executed, indicating high status or authority in the story

nodes.label: Mary Ann
nodes.title: The White Rabbit mistakes Alice for his housemaid named Mary Ann, demonstrating a class or social hierarchy

nodes.label: Dinah
nodes.title: Alice's cat, whom she imagines might send her on errands just as the White Rabbit does, signifying Alice's feelings about her unusual circumstances

nodes.label: W. RABBIT
nodes.title: Name on the brass plate which likely stands for the White Rabbit, denoting ownership of the house Alice enters

nodes.label: Pat
nodes.title: An unseen character the Rabbit speaks to after his fall, suggesting another creature or person in the story

nodes.label: Bill
nodes.title: A character who is instructed to fetch a ladder then later told to go down the chimney, suggesting a subordinate role to the Rabbit

nodes.label: Puppy
nodes.title: An animal Alice encounters which poses a threat due to its size, adding to her challenges

nodes.label: Large blue caterpillar
nodes.title: A character Alice meets who is smoking a hookah, adding to the surreal experience Alice is having

edges.label: worry about
edges.title: The White Rabbit was anxious and worried about The Duchess executing him.

edges.label: search for
edges.title: Alice guessed the White Rabbit was looking for the fan and the gloves and began hunting about for them.

edges.label: mistake for
edges.title: The White Rabbit mistook Alice for his housemaid Mary Ann and asked her to fetch gloves and a fan.

edges.label: hypothetical orders
edges.title: Alice imagined herself receiving and executing orders from Dinah similar to running errands for the White Rabbit.

edges.label: enter home of
edges.title: Alice said to herself, "How queer it seems... to be going messages for a rabbit! I suppose Dinah'll be sending me on messages next!" And she began fancying the sort of thing that would happen: ...

edges.label: intend to eat
edges.title: Alice considered eating a mushroom to change her size after seeing the Large blue caterpillar sitting on top of it.

edges.label: ignore
edges.title: The Large blue caterpillar was sitting on the mushroom, smoking a hookah, and ignoring Alice when she first saw it.

sectionName: CHAPTER V. Advice from a Caterpillar
summary: Alice encounters a Caterpillar who questions her identity, sparking a conversation about change and size. The Caterpillar advises Alice to keep her temper and later tells her that different parts of a mushroom will make her grow or shrink. As Alice experiments with these pieces, she changes size several times, eventually adjusting herself to her normal height. She also has a confusing encounter with a pigeon that mistakes her for a serpent. Alice aims to enter a beautiful garden and adjusts her size again to approach a little house.

nodes.label: Caterpillar
nodes.title: A languid, sleepy character that converses with Alice offering cryptic advice

nodes.label: Alice
nodes.title: The main character of the story who is undergoing many size changes and seeks to understand her own identity

nodes.label: Father William
nodes.title: A character in a poem recited by Alice who is known for his surprising vitality and agility despite his age

nodes.label: Pigeon
nodes.title: A character that mistakes Alice for a serpent and is concerned about protecting its eggs from said serpents

edges.label: address/question/not understand/disagree/dismiss/inquire/instruct/correct/assess/question/query/affirm/advise/inform
edges.title: Various interactions between the Caterpillar and Alice regarding their conversation, questions, and advice.

edges.label: reply/explain/express confusion/suggest change/express own feelings/request identity/express change/express difficulty/request/express indifference
edges.title: Alice's various responses and explanations to the Caterpillar as well as her requests and expressions of confusion and changes.

edges.label: deny/clarify
edges.title: Alice denying being a serpent and clarifying to the Pigeon that she's not looking for eggs.

edges.label: accuse/persist
edges.title: The Pigeon accusing Alice of being a serpent and persisting in its accusation.

summary: Alice observes a house and considers her next move when a fish-like footman delivers a letter inviting the Duchess to play croquet with the Queen; the door is answered by a frog-like footman. Alice laughs at their tangled hair but hides to avoid being heard. Approaching the house, she attempts to knock but is rebuked by the frog footman who informs her of the noisy chaos inside. After an exchange about the uselessness of knocking, Alice boldly enters the kitchen filled with smoke, where a sneezy environment caused by too much pepper affects everyone except the cook and a grinning Cheshire Cat. The Duchess nurses a baby in a violent manner and engages in brief, rude conversation with Alice before being pelted with kitchenware by the cook. Alice tries to discuss the earth's rotation, only to be interrupted by the Duchess, who abruptly leaves to prepare for croquet. Alice is left to care for the baby, which soon turns into a pig. A conversation with the Cheshire Cat leads her to contemplate going to visit the March Hare or the Hatter, as suggested by the Cat who keeps appearing and disappearing, leaving only its grin behind. The chapter ends with Alice approaching the March Hare's house ahead of deciding whether to visit there or the Hatter's abode.

nodes.label: Alice
nodes.title: The protagonist of the story who interacts with the footman and other curious characters

nodes.label: Fish-Footman
nodes.title: The footman with a face like a fish who delivers an invitation from the Queen

nodes.label: Frog-Footman
nodes.title: The footman with a face like a frog who interacts with Alice and the Fish-Footman

nodes.label: The Duchess
nodes.title: A character who is nursing a baby and throws the baby at Alice, later to play croquet with the Queen

nodes.label: The cook
nodes.title: The character who is cooking, engages in throwing objects around, and has a blase attitude towards Alice

nodes.label: Cheshire Cat
nodes.title: A grinning cat that engages in conversation with Alice and provides guidance and commentary

nodes.label: The baby
nodes.title: Initially cared for by the Duchess but transforms into a pig

nodes.label: The Hatter
nodes.title: Mentioned by the Cheshire Cat as a resident one can visit, implied to be mad

nodes.label: The March Hare
nodes.title: Mentioned by the Cheshire Cat and the destination Alice considers visiting, implied to be mad

edges.label: invite
edges.title: The Fish-Footman began by producing a great letter, for the Duchess, an invitation from the Queen to play croquet.

edges.label: invite
edges.title: The Frog-Footman repeated the invitation for the Duchess to play croquet.

edges.label: nurse
edges.title: The Duchess was nursing the baby.

edges.label: suggest
edges.title: The Cheshire Cat suggests Alice visit either the Hatter or the March Hare.

edges.label: predict
edges.title: The Cheshire Cat predicted the baby would turn into a pig.

edges.label: nurse
edges.title: Alice tried to nurse the baby proper before it turned into a pig.

edges.label: transform
edges.title: The baby transformed into a pig.

edges.label: be seen
edges.title: Alice contemplated visiting the March Hare.

summary: Alice encounters the March Hare, the Hatter, and a sleeping Dormouse having a nonsensical tea party. They discuss the concept of saying what one means, the relativity of time, and exchange riddles and stories which have no answers or logic. When offended by their rudeness and absurdities, Alice leaves the frustrating tea party and finally enters the garden she has been seeking by growing to the appropriate size using a piece of mushroom she saved.

nodes.label: Alice
nodes.title: The main character who interacts with others at the tea party and expresses confusion and curiosity

nodes.label: The March Hare
nodes.title: A character who hosts the tea party with the Hatter and engages in nonsensical conversations and riddles

nodes.label: The Hatter
nodes.title: Another host of the tea party known for his eccentric manners, questioning of time, and nonsensical poetry

nodes.label: The Dormouse
nodes.title: A character at the tea party who falls asleep frequently and is used as a cushion by the others, also tells a story about three sisters

edges.label: thought uncomfortable
edges.title: Alice thought "Very uncomfortable for the Dormouse."

edges.label: offered wine and accused of incivility (twice)
edges.title: The March Hare said “Have some wine,” but Alice accused The March Hare of being uncivil for offering wine that wasn't there and for saying it was uncivil of her to sit down uninvited.

edges.label: commented on appearance
edges.title: asked riddle, and disagreed on meaning equivalency, The Hatter made a comment about Alice's appearance, asked a riddle about a raven and a writing-desk, and disagreed on the equivalency of meanings with Alice.

edges.label: reprimanded for rudeness
edges.title: Alice said "You should learn not to make personal remarks; it's very rude."

edges.label: added argument & was asked for a story
edges.title: The Dormouse said "You might just as well say that ‘I breathe when I sleep’ is the same thing as ‘I sleep when I breathe’!" & The Dormouse was asked by The Hatter and The March Hare to tell a story to Alice.

edges.label: suggested a story
edges.title: The March Hare suggested that The Dormouse should tell a story.

summary: Alice encounters three gardeners painting white roses red to correct their mistake of planting the wrong rose tree and avoid the Queen's punishment. The Queen arrives with a grand procession and demands the beheading of the gardeners, but Alice intervenes, helping them avoid execution. Alice then joins the Queen's bizarre croquet game, where the equipment is alive. The Cheshire Cat reappears, causing a dispute about its beheading due to its disembodied state, but the problem is unresolved as the Duchess, whom the Cat belongs to, is in prison.

nodes.label: Alice
nodes.title: A curious and polite young girl who is the protagonist in the story

nodes.label: Five
nodes.title: One of the gardeners painting the roses red

nodes.label: Seven
nodes.title: Another gardener who also blames others for mistakes

nodes.label: Two
nodes.title: A gardener who explains why they must paint the roses red

nodes.label: The Queen of Hearts
nodes.title: A quick-tempered monarch who commands everyone around her

nodes.label: The King of Hearts
nodes.title: A relatively timid character compared to the Queen, somewhat sympathetic towards Alice

nodes.label: The White Rabbit
nodes.title: A nervous and timid character that Alice follows into Wonderland and who interacts with her during the croquet game

nodes.label: The Knave of Hearts
nodes.title: A character who carries the King's crown and is present during the croquet game

nodes.label: The Cheshire Cat
nodes.title: A cat that appears and disappears at will, engages in conversation with Alice, and causes a dispute

nodes.label: The Duchess
nodes.title: A character who is mentioned as under sentence of execution and who is known by the Cheshire Cat

sectionName: CHAPTER IX. The Mock Turtle’s Story
summary: Alice and the Duchess bond over theories of temperament, morality, and Alice's flamingo in the croquet game. The threatening Queen of Hearts reappears, causing the Duchess to hurriedly depart. The Queen then introduces Alice to the Gryphon to meet the melancholic Mock Turtle and hear his history, which includes a bizarre education in the sea. They discuss their schooling experiences, revealing the absurd curriculum of the sea creatures, before the Gryphon diverts the conversation to games.

nodes.label: Alice
nodes.title: A young girl who finds herself in whimsical situations in Wonderland, interacting and pondering upon various philosophical concepts and characters

nodes.label: Duchess
nodes.title: A character whom Alice encounters; she engages in conversation regarding morals and societal rules with Alice

nodes.label: Queen
nodes.title: A powerful figure in Wonderland who threatens execution; has an encounter with Alice and commands her regarding the Mock Turtle

nodes.label: Mock Turtle
nodes.title: A sorrowful character that Alice is led to by the Gryphon; shares his story and reflects on various abstract educational topics

nodes.label: Gryphon
nodes.title: A creature that accompanies Alice to meet the Mock Turtle and comments on his story and reflects its own perspective

edges.label: express affection/close proximity/share wisdom
edges.title: The Duchess was glad to see Alice, tucked her arm affectionately into hers, squeezed closer to Alice, and shared her views on morals.

edges.label: issue a threat/respond to threat
edges.title: The Queen warned the Duchess, resulting in the Duchess immediately leaving.

edges.label: command/inquire/give an order
edges.title: The Queen told Alice to continue the game, asked if she had seen the Mock Turtle, and instructed her to visit the Mock Turtle and hear his history.

edges.label: introduce
edges.title: The Queen instructed the Gryphon to take Alice to the Mock Turtle.

edges.label: make a request
edges.title: The Gryphon asked the Mock Turtle to share his history with Alice.

edges.label: teach
edges.title: The Mock Turtle agreed to tell his history to Alice.

summary: The Mock Turtle describes the Lobster Quadrille, a whimsical sea dance, to Alice, who finds it interesting though confusing. The Gryphon and the Mock Turtle attempt to demonstrate the dance and offer to share more curious information about sea creatures and their ways. Alice tries to share her own adventures, but they insist on hearing verses which end up nonsensical due to her distraction by the Lobster Quadrille, leading to more confusion. Eventually, they are interrupted by a call announcing the start of a trial, and the Gryphon hurries Alice away, leaving the song of the Mock Turtle trailing behind them.

nodes.label: Alice
nodes.title: A curious and polite young girl who finds herself in fantastical situations

nodes.label: Mock Turtle
nodes.title: A character who is a parody of a turtle in the story and seems to be quite melancholic

nodes.label: Gryphon
nodes.title: A mythical creature who accompanies the Mock Turtle and Alice, showing a somewhat impatient demeanor

nodes.label: Whiting
nodes.title: A fish mentioned in the Mock Turtle's song, personified to take part in the dance

nodes.label: Snail
nodes.title: Another creature mentioned in the song, who refuses to join the dance

nodes.label: Porpoise
nodes.title: Referenced in conversation between Alice and the Mock Turtle as part of a joke

nodes.label: Lobsters
nodes.title: Invoked as dance partners in the Lobster Quadrille, though not directly interacting characters

edges.label: looked & offer
edges.title: The Mock Turtle looked at Alice. & The Mock Turtle offered to show Alice a little of the Lobster Quadrille dance.

edges.label: help & sing
edges.title: The Gryphon set to work shaking him (Mock Turtle) and punching him in the back. & The Gryphon told the Mock Turtle "Oh, you sing," when asked which of them should sing.

edges.label: explain
edges.title: The Gryphon explained to Alice how to perform the Lobster Quadrille.

edges.label: instruct
edges.title: The Mock Turtle instructed the Gryphon to come and try the first figure of the dance.

edges.label: invite
edges.title: The Whiting invited the Snail to join the dance in the song sung by the Mock Turtle.

edges.label: refuse
edges.title: The Snail refused the Whiting's invitation to join the dance.

edges.label: express
edges.title: Alice expressed to the Mock Turtle "Very much indeed," showing her interest in seeing the dance.

edges.label: need
edges.title: The Mock Turtle said to Alice "They were obliged to have him with them," indicating the need for a porpoise.

sectionName: CHAPTER XI. Who Stole the Tarts?
summary: The King and Queen of Hearts preside over a court with various creatures and the pack of cards. Alice is observing the absurd trial where the Knave of Hearts is accused of stealing tarts. The court proceedings are nonsensical, with jurors writing down their names so they don't forget, and the Hatter is called as a witness. He gives a confused testimony, prompting the King to become impatient and threaten execution. The Hatter's evidence is incoherent, discussing his tea-time and ignoring the case. The situation becomes more chaotic as the Dormouse's comments lead to his ejection from the court. The cook is the next witness, who rudely refuses to testify, adding to the disarray. Eventually, much to Alice's surprise, she is called as the next witness.

nodes.label: King of Hearts
nodes.title: The judge and ruler presiding over the trial

nodes.label: Queen of Hearts
nodes.title: The monarch who made the tarts that were stolen

nodes.label: Knave of Hearts
nodes.title: The accused who allegedly stole the tarts

nodes.label: White Rabbit
nodes.title: The herald in the court who reads the accusation

nodes.label: Alice
nodes.title: A visitor to the court and growing larger, causing disruption

nodes.label: Gryphon
nodes.title: The creature that explains the jurors' actions to Alice

nodes.label: Hatter
nodes.title: The first witness called during the trial

nodes.label: March Hare
nodes.title: Companion to the Hatter, involved in the witness testimony

nodes.label: Dormouse
nodes.title: Another companion to the Hatter and the subject of courtroom commotion

nodes.label: Bill the Lizard
nodes.title: A juror whose pencil Alice takes away

nodes.label: Duchess's cook
nodes.title: A witness at the trial who carries a pepper-box

nodes.label: Soldier
nodes.title: Guarde who stand beside the Knave

nodes.label: Officer of the Court
nodes.title: Individual responsible for suppression during the trial

nodes.label: Jury
nodes.title: The twelve creatures writing on slates, determining the verdict

edges.label: seated
edges.title: The King and Queen of Hearts were seated on their throne.

edges.label: guarded
edges.title: The Knave was standing before the King and Queen, in chains, with a soldier on each side to guard him.

edges.label: near
edges.title: Near the King was the White Rabbit.

edges.label: called as witness
edges.title: The King called the Hatter as the first witness.

edges.label: looked at
edges.title: The Hatter looked at the March Hare.

summary: Alice, having grown large, accidentally upsets the jury box at her trial, and the King rules that the trial cannot continue until the jurors are in their proper places. When questioned by the King, Alice declares she knows nothing of the matter at hand. The proceedings become more absurd as a letter with nonsensical verses is presented as evidence, with no one able to interpret it. The Queen demands a verdict before evidence is fully heard, but Alice, now full-sized, refutes the nonsensical proceedings. The Queen orders Alice's beheading, but as the cards fly at Alice, she wakes up to find herself on the bank with her sister. It was all a dream, which she recounts to her sister before being called in for tea. Her sister stays behind, contemplating Alice's dream and dreaming herself of Alice's future growth, retaining her childlike heart and sharing her Wonderland adventures with other children.

nodes.label: Alice
nodes.title: The protagonist of the story who inadvertently causes chaos in the court

nodes.label: Jurymen
nodes.title: Members of the jury that Alice knocks over, affecting the trial

nodes.label: King
nodes.title: The authority presiding over the trial, making important decisions

nodes.label: Lizard (Bill)
nodes.title: A jurymen character whom Alice puts incorrectly into the jury-box

nodes.label: White Rabbit
nodes.title: A court attendant and herald who provides evidence at the trial

nodes.label: Queen
nodes.title: An authority figure who seeks to enforce rules and deliver sentences in the trial

nodes.label: Knave
nodes.title: The accused in the trial, whose guilt or innocence is being determined

nodes.label: Alice's Sister
nodes.title: Appears at the end of the narrative, indicating the adventure was a dream

edges.label: tip over & pick up
edges.title: Alice tipped over the jury-box with the edge of her skirt, upsetting all the jurymen, and began picking them up again as quickly as she could after upsetting them.

edges.label: put right
edges.title: Alice put the Lizard right after noticing it was put in head downwards.

edges.label: question & height accusation & rule defense
edges.title: The King asked Alice what she knew about the trial's business. & The King accused Alice of being more than a mile high. & The King defended the court rule as the oldest in the book.

edges.label: response & rule challenge
edges.title: Alice told the King she knew "Nothing" about the trial's business. & Alice challenged the King on the creation of a court rule.

edges.label: correct & instruction
edges.title: The King corrected the White Rabbit's statement, emphasizing it was "important." & The King instructed the jury to consider their verdict.

edges.label: correct & evidence introduction
edges.title: The White Rabbit corrected the King by saying "unimportant." & The White Rabbit informed the King of new evidence.

edges.label: height accusation & verdict demand & execution order
edges.title: The Queen added that Alice was nearly two miles high. & The Queen demanded a sentence before the verdict from Alice. & The Queen ordered Alice's execution.

edges.label: evidence update
edges.title: The White Rabbit updated the Queen that the paper was a set of verses.

edges.label: attack
edges.title: The Queen threw an inkstand at Lizard (Bill).

edges.label: refusal
edges.title: Alice refused to comply with the Queen's demand.

edges.label: awaken & consolation
edges.title: Alice's Sister woke Alice up from her dream. & Alice's Sister comforted Alice after she narrated her dream.
